abstract.p: The evacuated tube solar water heaters are widely in use today. But so far their thermal performance has not been systematically evaluated, despite the increased popularity. An experimental solar hot water system including two collector types, namely water-in-glass and heat-pipe, of evacuated tube solar water heater has been set up. Their capacity is typical for serving single family domestic hot water system. Performance tests were carried out in Hong Kong and under almost identical boundary conditions by placing the two collectors side-by-side. The energy performance has been analysed and the daily efficiency, transient efficiency and night-time heat loss were compared. While the energy acquisition performance of the heat-pipe collector design is found slightly better, the heat loss performance is found weaker than the water-in-glass collector design.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: To fight against global climate change and air pollution problem of the city, there are increased interests in solar energy applications in Hong Kong. Hot water production is one of the government promoted applications because of the proven technology and good economic return [1, 2]. The cost effectiveness of solar thermal collectors is known to depend on the cost of collector components, the efficiency and the thermal losses associated with the collector at the local operating condition.

Flat plate solar water heaters are traditionally in use in domestic hot water (DHW) systems because of the low temperature requirement (approximately 35–50 °C) and low equipment cost [3, 4]. In recent years, the advancements in heating and air-conditioning technology have called for solar-assisted air-conditioning and heat-pump designs [5–7], in that there is a market for the evacuated-tube solar water heaters. In absorption cooling machines, the water must be heated up to at least 75–80 °C. Compared with the flat-plate collectors, the evacuated-tube collectors are able to generate hot water up to 110 °C because of the lower heat loss at surface, and thus result in higher collector efficiency. Particularly in cold places, the winter water freezing problem can be minimized.

Currently there are two types of evacuated-tube solar water heaters available in the market: (i) the open single-phase water-in-glass (WG) type, and (ii) the closed two-phase heat-pipe (HP) type. Both can work with forced flow or natural circulation mode in the manifold header. Comparatively, the WG type is more commonly in use today since they are simpler in construction and lower in manufacturing costs [8]. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the WG type consists of two concentric borosilicate glass tubes sealed at one end. The annular space between the two tubes is evacuated. The selective coating at the outside of the inner glass tube increases solar absorption and reduces heat radiance losses. This is designed for single-phase open thermosyphon, in that heat absorption at the inner tube creates a buoyant flow of water up the tube and accordingly, replaced by an inflow of cold water from the tank. Mechanical pump is not required. Alternatively, the HP type is designed for closed two-phase fluid flow. It has a sealed borosilicate glass tube and a sealed metallic (e.g. copper) tube with a working fluid in it and a metal (e.g. aluminum) fin. The selective coating is applied on the inner cover of the outer glass tube. The length of the inner metallic tube is divided into the lower evaporation section and the upper condenser section, or sometimes with an adiabatic section in between. The liquid pool in the evaporation section absorbs the transmitted heat and turns into vapour, which then rises to the upper condenser section, where the vapour returns to liquid that runs back to the liquid pool at the lower evaporation section by gravity. It is the latent heat released by the working fluid that heats up the water in the storage tank. Fig. 1
Two types of evacuated tube solar water heaters: (a) the WG type, and (b) the HP type

Although the two mentioned evacuated tube water heaters are relatively mature products, it has come to our attention that the thermal performance of these two has not been systematically evaluated and/or fully disclosed to the users. As a matter of facts, the flow structure in the single-phase thermosyphon is highly complicated. From fundamental theory, the cold and hot water streams are separated by a shear layer; rotational flow exists at each tube cross-section despite that stagnant zone may co-exist at the dead end. The natural buoyant flow rate and pattern are affected by factors like collector inclination (which determines the axial and radial components of the gravitational acceleration), and the tube length-to-diameter ratio (which affects the Nusselt number correlation). In the heat-pipe system, the performance is complicated by the regimes of boiling and condensing processes. The heat flow is also affected by the thermal properties of the working fluid in use as well as the fill-ratio. On the other hand, the final heat delivery to the water storage is affected by the tube-array configuration, materials, surface coating, as well as stratified tank design. Besides, the ever-changing incident solar irradiation both in magnitude and direction makes the integrated thermal process highly dynamic and stochastic. Standardized experimental test is deemed one most reliable method to compare collector system performance.
In this article, the related previous research works from literatures are first summarized. Then an experimental study which compared their thermal performance is presented.

sec.title: 2.1 Water-in-glass evacuated tube design
sec.p: Many theoretical and experimental works on evacuated tube solar collectors can be traced back to 1980s. The performance characteristics of evacuated tube arrays were evaluated using either measurement techniques or ray-tracing simulations. Window and Zybert [9] used the Monte-Carlo ray tracing technique to determine the fraction of solar radiation collected by arrays of cylindrical absorbers with diffuse reflectors. For fluid-in-glass design, the experimental work of Window [10] found that the absorber tube at tilt angles of 10° and 45° (but not 80°) gave good heat extraction results; the most effective heat transfer occurred when the average tube surface temperature was typically 1–2 °C above the outlet water temperature.

The collector efficiency can be determined as the ratio of the collected useful energy to the available solar radiation during the measuring period. Using this calorimetric measurement, the heat gain of the collector is calculated from the temperature increase in the evacuated tubes over a short period of steady solar radiation. Chow et al. [11] in Sydney (33.55 °S, 151.10 °E) Australia determined the efficiencies of arrays of evacuated tubular collectors with diffuse reflectors both theoretically (ray tracing) and experimentally (calorimetric). They found that the collector efficiency was not strongly dependent on the reflectance of the diffuse reflector, but rather depending strongly on the collector tube separation. Also in Sydney, the efficiency of the evacuated tubular collector system was found about 1.8 times that of a non-selective flat plate system and about 1.3 times that of a high-quality selective flat plate system [12]. It was also predicted that these factors could be likely amplified at places with lower ambient temperature and insolation level. Yin and Harding [13] showed that for a wide range of operating conditions, efficient heat output of all-glass evacuated tube collector with a copper manifold can be maintained by the thermosyphon effect. The thermal performance of all-glass evacuated tube collectors with absorber coating on the outside and inside of the inner tube was studied by Estrada-Gasca et al. [14]. Their mathematical model determined that applying the absorber film on the external surface of the inner tube is the better design.

More recent works on water-in-glass evacuated tube solar collectors, including the natural thermosyphon flow related to single-ended tube, were carried out in the University of New South Wales in Australia. The collector performance was first investigated by Morrison et al. [15] using the International Standard test method ISO 9459-2 and a simple mathematical model, which illustrates the possible existence of a stagnant zone at the bottom end of the tube. Further, their CFD simulation results showed that the natural convection flow rate in the single-ended tube is high enough to disturb the tank’s stratification [16]. The tank water temperature was found strongly affecting the circulation flow rate through the tubes. Also the circumferential heat distribution was found to be an important parameter influencing the flow structure and the circulation flow rate through the tubing. The natural circulation flow rate for single-ended tube mounted over a diffuse reflector was correlated in terms of solar input, tank temperature, collector inclination and tube aspect ratio [17]. Budihardjo et al. [18] found that in Sydney when the water-in-glass evacuated tube collector inclination is increased to 45°, the annual saving during winter months is 12 per cent higher than when the collector is inclined at a standard roof inclination of 22°. Also the performance of evacuated tube collector system was shown to be less sensitive to tank size than flat plate collector systems.

In Italy, Zambolin and Del Col [19] compared the performance of the flat plate collector and the evacuated tube collector in stationary and quasi-dynamic conditions. A standard glazed flat plate collector and a single-phase thermosyphon type evacuated tube collector with external compound parabolic concentrator reflectors were installed side-by-side in Padova (45.42 °N, 11.88 °E), with a mixture of water and propylene glycol as the working fluid. They were tested at the same working conditions based on the European Standard EN 12975-2. An echo to the previous works was concluded in the daily test that the evacuated collector, as compared to the flat plate collector, displays a higher efficiency for a larger range of operating conditions.

The above works are on vertical tubular systems. By means of a CFD model, Shah and Furbo [20] studied the all-glass evacuated tubular collector design with horizontal tubes connected to a vertical manifold channel. They found that the collector design works well for a wide range of operating conditions, and the shorter tube length may achieve higher efficiency.

sec.title: 2.2 Heat-pipe evacuated tube design
sec.p: The reported works on heat-pipe evacuated tube solar water heaters, especially the popular single-tube two-phase closed evaporative design, are so far very limited.

Yan et al. [21] compared the thermal efficiency of (i) the inserted non-evaporative heat-pipe design with (ii) the water-in-glass design. The test was carried out at Hohhot (40.85 °N, 111.67 °E) China, based on the Chinese National Standard GB/T 18708-2002. Both tubes are of dimensions 58 mm (D) × 1500 mm (L), in association with a 10-L water storage tank. The heat-pipe was a 1.4 m totally-sealed copper tube and filled with air as the heat transport fluid. Their performance test showed that the inserted heat-pipe design has instantaneous thermal efficiency around 15 per cent higher than the water-in-glass design.

Yu et al. [22] carried out experimental investigation of a cellular heat-pipe flat solar heater (CHP) as compared to the water-in-glass evacuated glass tube solar heater (WG), when they were placed side-by-side. The cellular solar heater in their tests was composed of heat pipes with fins, a metallic casing with thermal insulation, a front glass cover, and a cellular interlayer between the cover and the heat pipes. The cellular interlayer was aimed at restraining the heat loss between the cover and endothermic board. The performance test, carried out in Hangzhou (30.18 °N, 120.07 °E) China, was based on the Chinese National Standard GB/T 12915-91 and GB 4271-84. The daily average efficiency of the CHP was found 15 per cent higher than the WG when the water temperature was below 65 °C. When the temperature was above 65 °C, the daily average efficiency of the CHP was 14 per cent lower than that of the WG. The average coefficient of heat loss for CHP was 54 per cent lower than the WG. They further pointed out that since the temperature of DHW system is usually at about 50 °C, the cellular heat-pipe design is comparatively better.

Chen et al. [23] investigated experimentally the long-term thermal performance of a two-phase thermosyphon solar water heater system comprises an energy storage tank and a two-phase closed thermsyphon loop. They were housed in a casing with a transparent polycarbonate plastic front cover. The thermosyphon loop includes three parts: (i) vertical collector tubes in copper at the front, (ii) a double-pipe heat exchanger at the upper part of the energy storage tank, and (iii) parallel-fin tubes inside the tank. The working fluid was alcohol at 40 per cent fill ratio. This two-phase system was found showing better thermal performance when compared with the conventional evacuated tube collector system and also several flat plate collector systems.

Amatachaya and Srimuang [24] compared the heat transfer characteristics of a flat (oval-tube) two-phase closed thermosyphon with a conventional circular-tube two-phase closed thermosyphon system. The effects of cross-sectional geometries, filling ratio and aspect ratio were investigated experimentally. It was found that the temperature variation along the wall of the evaporator section of the conventional two-phase thermosyphon system was uniform and decreased slightly along the condensation section. In the flat two-phase thermosyphon design, it was higher. The maximum heat input had significant influence on the heat flux for each filling ratio and evaporator length. While the thermal performance was found slightly affected by the filling ratio, the heat flux increased with the aspect ratio and only decreased slightly before reaching the maximum aspect ratio.

The above review shows that so far there was no (or very little) previous experimental work on comparing the thermal performance of the water-in-glass and the heat-pipe evacuated tube solar water heaters currently available in the commercial market, despite of their popularity. This is then the main purpose of our work here described.

sec.title: 3.1 Experimental rig
sec.p:
An experimental rig with the mentioned two common types of evacuated tube collectors was developed at the roof of the academic building at the City University of Hong Kong (Fig. 2(a) and (b)). The two commercial collectors (WG and HP types) were supplied from the same manufacturer in China and with almost the same dimensions, materials and arrangements. The tubing arrays of these side-by-side collectors were set south-facing at the tilt angle of 33°. Each collector carried a 150-litre water storage tank, 14 numbers of tubes of length 2.1 m, and an overall collector aperture area of 1.561 m2. The inner and outer glass tubes were of diameters 47 mm and 58 mm, respectively. No diffuse reflector was equipped. The key technical data of the collector system is given in Table 1. Fig. 2

This collector system is composed of four major parts: floor-mounted solar collectors, storage tanks, feed tank, and piping system with circulation pump. A configuration diagram is shown in Fig. 3. 29 numbers of copper-constantan thermocouples were fixed at different positions of the solar collector system, including the pipes and the storage tanks for temperature data acquisition. A list of testing and monitoring devices is given in Table 2. The indicative positions of the sensors installed at the experimental rig can be seen in Fig. 4, and with the positions of the thermocouples described in Table 3. Performance data were acquired in a 6-month period from January to July. All measurement data were collected at 1-min intervals by the Agilent 34970A data logger connected to a desktop computer. Water in storage tanks were automatically mixed in the early morning, and also in the evening hours through the circulating pump. Hence the water temperature conditions were the same at the start of the daily test and the heat loss test at night. The circulating pump remained stationary in the rest of the period, and hence only natural stratified water flow took place in the storage tank during the standard tests. The useful energy gain was then determined from the increase of storage tank temperature over the day. Fig. 3

This is because after the sunset, the WG evacuated tube starts to loss heat energy to the ambient and its water temperature drops below the water temperature in tank. sec.title: 4.1 Daily system efficiency
sec.p: From equations (8) and (9), it can be seen that at no loss condition, the daily system efficiency of the HP type (at 0.5375) is slightly higher than the WG type (at 0.5214). The absolute difference is marginally at around 1.6 per cent. On the other hand, the overall system loss coefficient of the HP type (at 0.08957) is much higher than the WG type (at 0.05524). Hence the HP type faces higher efficiency drop at elevated water temperature.

From Tables 4 and 5, it can be observed that when the average tank water temperature during the energy collecting period was below 40 °C, the daily system efficiency of the HP type was higher than the WG type. At between 40 °C and 55 °C, the daily efficiency of the two were close. But when the average water temperature during the collecting period was higher than 55 °C, the daily efficiency of the WG type was higher than the HP type. The reason is that the heat loss of the HP type is bigger than the WG type when the average water temperature is high. Since the temperature requirement of a DHW system is about 50 °C, therefore the energy performance of the HP type is better than the WG type considering the generally low feed water temperature at the beginning of the day.

sec.title: 4.2 Transient system efficiency
sec.p:
Figure 7(a) and (b) show respectively the solar radiation on two typical testing days, one in winter (14 January 2009) and the other in summer (9 July 2009). Both are sunny days with more or less symmetrical distribution of solar radiation on collector plane across the day. The maximum solar radiation levels on 14 January and 9 July are 946 and 869 W/m2, respectively. Fig. 7
Variation of solar radiation on: (a) a typical winter day, and (b) a typical summer day

Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the transient system efficiencies of these two collector types for ready comparisons. It can be seen that the two collector types followed very similar behaviour trend in these two typical days. In the early morning, the transient efficiency of the WG type is higher than the HP type. At the noon time, the difference in transient efficiency of the two systems is not significant. In the late afternoon, the transient efficiency of the HP type is higher than the WG type. It appears that longer time duration is required for the HP type to transmit the absorbed solar heat to the water in tank. As a consequence of the time delay, the transient efficiency of the HP type can be exceptionally high after 4 pm (even more than 100 per cent in one case). Fig. 8

sec.p: For heat-pipe type (10)

For water-in-glass type, (11) Hence the system coefficient of heat loss of the HP type (at 1.356) is considerably higher than the WG type (at 0.8484) at no loss condition. This is deemed owing to the higher thermal conduction and radiation loss through the copper tubing and aluminum fin surfaces than the water-in-glass. This heat loss rate is affected very little by the water-and-ambient temperature difference because the slopes of the two regression lines are mild and are close in magnitude (0.00841 versus 0.00989).

It can be seen from the above analysis that the thermal and optical characteristics of the WG system and the HP system are comparable. Although the long-term daily performance of the HP design is slightly better than the WG design, the manufacturing costs of the former is much higher. Hence the practical selection between these two collector types may not be mainly judged by their thermal performance but rather by other engineering factors. For instance, there are at least two advantages of the HP design over the WG design.
When one evacuated tube has broken, the WG system can no long operate since the water in tank will be drained away through the broken tube; however, the HP system can still operate because of the closed-loop thermosyphon working principle.
Under extreme cold weather conditions (−30 °C for instance), the WG system may have chance to get water frozen in tube, whereas the HP system does not have such problem and can still function well.

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: An experimental solar hot water system including two collector types, namely water-in-glass and heat-pipe, of the evacuated tube solar water heater has been set up to compare their thermal performance. The collector capacity in tests is typical for serving single family DHW system. Performance tests across six months were carried out with the side-by-side collectors and under almost identical boundary conditions. The energy performance has been assessed in three aspects: daily efficiency, transient efficiency and night-time heat loss, in accordance with the Taiwan Testing Standard CNS B7277 and Chinese National Standards GB/T 12915-91 and 18708-2002.

The following conclusions can be drawn from the experimental data analysis.
The daily system efficiency of the heat-pipe type is slightly higher than the water-in-glass type. The difference gradually diminishes when the water temperature in tank has been built up in the morning. The implication is that the heat-pipe design is marginally better than the water-in-glass design for DHW system applications in the subtropical Hong Kong environment.
In the morning, the transient system efficiency of the water-in-glass type is higher than the heat-pipe type. Around the noon time, the difference in transient efficiency of the two systems is not significant. In the late afternoon, the transient efficiency of the heat-pipe design is higher than the water-in-glass design.
The night-time system coefficient of heat loss of heat-pipe type is higher than the water-in-glass type. This implies that the overnight thermal storage of the heat-pipe design is inferior to the water-in-glass design.

Overall speaking, the thermal and optical characteristics of the single-phase open water-in-glass system and the two-phase closed thermosyphon system are comparable. The long-term daily performance of the heat pipe design is found only slightly better than the water-in-glass design. Moreover, the water-in-glass design has better energy storage characteristics than the heat-pipe counterpart. Hence, the practical selection between these two collector types may not be mainly based on the thermal performance but rather on complementary engineering factors.
